name: NPR
text: When the 63rd annual Grammy Awards ceremony airs on Sunday, Jan, 31, the show will probably be unlike any Grammys we've seen before. There's still a ton of great music to celebrate, and many of this year's nominated artists are World Cafe alumni. https://t.co/p2kqFEaXg4

name: NPR
text:
Despite recent megafires, most states don't require homeowners to rebuild with fire-resistant materials.

"It does feel very much like a missed opportunity," a research engineer says. "We're right there with the opportunity to build back stronger."
https://t.co/GxAoDFlTb7

name: NPR
text: In David Chang's memoir Eat a Peach, the chef he writes about his struggle with bipolar disorder and suicidal thoughts — and explains how cooking and his restaurants have helped save his life. https://t.co/a6vVa9QMQz

name: NPR
text:
RT @hansilowang: BREAKING: In a 2-1 split decision, a three-judge federal court in DC has dismissed the Common Cause-led lawsuit over Trump's census apportionment memo after finding it "not ripe for review" (SCOTUS hears Nov. 30 oral arguments for appeal of NY-based case)
https://t.co/EjNylE5enX https://t.co/5QbyaMBRU9

name: NPR
text:
Before the election, a 9-year-old asked Doug Emhoff what he would do if his wife, Kamala Harris, became vice president.

He answered: "I'm just gonna do what I always do … I'm gonna support her."
https://t.co/M13ypJXoFS

name: NPR
text:
Comedian Dave Chappelle had a strange request for his fans. Don't stream his show.

"I'm begging you. If you ever liked me," he said in a video of a standup routine he shared on Tuesday. "Boycott 'Chappelle's Show.' Do not watch it unless they pay me." https://t.co/V6RkSsLQlx

name: NPR
text: The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers says it has determined that the plan "does not comply with Clean Water Act guidelines" and it had concluded that "the proposed project is contrary to the public interest." https://t.co/VxMFY0b6Cd

name: NPR
text:
While the CDC has recommended that people not gather for Thanksgiving, the reality is millions are traveling. 

So, #NPRShortWave spoke to experts about how to mitigate some risk during a gathering. https://t.co/hSepdR1uvy

name: NPR
text:
Scotland has passed the The Period Products (Free Provision) (Scotland) Bill.

The bill, which passed unanimously, requires local authorities to ensure that period products are generally obtainable free of charge. https://t.co/hA8feSwmw0

name: NPR
text:
There are far more people hospitalized for COVID-19 now than at any other moment of the pandemic — more than twice as many as just a month ago.

Many states are warning they're on the brink. https://t.co/uBYu76mh2e

name: NPR
text:
RT @witfnews: Some people see a big opportunity for Pennsylvania to lead the charge into the clean energy economy that President-elect Joe Biden is calling for.
https://t.co/Wd64bBkene via @StateImpactPA

name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: Thanksgiving during a pandemic isn’t ideal, but it can still be memorable. And rethinking the celebration can include rethinking the traditional holiday meal. Today on #NPRConsiderThis, three chefs share their scaled-down Thanksgiving recipes.
https://t.co/EsiSw9A8Xp

name: NPR
text:
For many Latinos, soccer is almost a religion. 

And Diego Armando Maradona, who died Wednesday at 60, was a saint for the faithful. https://t.co/uo9gkq8gKg

name: NPR
text: Like many small business owners, Kelly Fields is walking a fine line between keeping her restaurant open and her employees safe. As much as she's staying vigilant, she's wary of another shutdown. https://t.co/wtNXwPeZP8

name: NPR
text:
NFL fans will still have games to watch on Thanksgiving. 

The Houston Texans and the Detroit Lions will play at 12:30 p.m. ET, and the Washington Football Team and the Dallas Cowboys play at 4:30 p.m. ET. https://t.co/3ujpTQcBCp

name: NPR
text: The day before Thanksgiving offered a jarring contrast between President-elect Joe Biden and President Trump, who has yet to concede he lost the election. https://t.co/ZlwRYPoHLG

name: NPR
text: More than 2,400 hospitals and related facilities have received their first doses of new drugs that are designed to keep mild to moderately ill COVID-19 patients out of the hospital. https://t.co/5Fev5d8lST

name: NPR
text: Restrictions and regulations implemented by the Defense Department to prevent the spread of the coronavirus have put a stop to holiday travel in many military installations. https://t.co/4TUPPtW5Z1

name: NPR
text: With coronavirus cases spiking across the country, Macy's will hold a modified version of its Thanksgiving Day Parade. https://t.co/Xp79Gcn8LM

name: NPR
text:
Concerns about how to charge electric cars — where to do it, how long it takes, why different chargers take different amounts of time — are tripping up would-be buyers.

That presents a challenge for automakers.
https://t.co/xjhAtQBJnD

name: NPR
text:
"We're at war with the virus, not with one another," President-elect Biden said the day before Thanksgiving.

Meanwhile, President Trump repeated baseless claims that the election was "rigged." https://t.co/ueB00MWZdy

name: NPR
text:
Suni Paz has been an unsung hero of the folk music world — until now. 

The National Endowment for the Arts has named her one of this year's Heritage Fellows, the most prestigious award for folk and traditional artists. https://t.co/XV0TrPuLwe

name: NPR
text: Hospitals in some of the hardest-hit states are exhausting every health care worker, hospital room and piece of equipment to evade a scenario where crisis plans have to be set in motion and care may have to be rationed. https://t.co/0L497ROPsp

name: NPR
text:
Antony Blinken, President-elect Biden's pick to head the State Department, has a wealth of diplomatic experience under his belt.

He also has a self-described "wonk rock" band called ABlinken, with two original songs streaming on Spotify. https://t.co/hxSZSo8vA4

name: NPR
text:
Lorena Bobbitt’s story made headlines across the world, but the truth of what happened to her was much more complex than you may have thought.
 
A new story on @radioambulante, our Spanish-language podcast. https://t.co/MN3fTIzJxM

name: NPR
text:
A federal court in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday tossed out a lawsuit filed against President Trump's efforts to exclude undocumented immigrants from a key set of census numbers. 
https://t.co/ZI4QfmeEIF

name: NPR
text: President-elect Joe Biden is set to soon name a second high-level climate position in the White House, a counterpart to his diplomatic climate envoy John Kerry. https://t.co/YLpNffP9Ml

name: NPR
text: Older populations are less consumed by pandemic depression than those that are younger and some seniors have even expanded their social support networks during the lockdowns, a recent study says. https://t.co/k94npPuiXD

name: NPR
text:
Lo que Lorena Bobbitt hizo para defenderse de su marido en 1993 la puso en el centro de la atención mediática. Pero poco se habló del infierno que le tocó vivir en su propio hogar.

Escuchen su historia en @radioambulante, nuestro podcast en español. https://t.co/nA7bMssBS9

name: NPR
text: A recent report issued by the Vatican casts a dark cloud over the late Pope John Paul II. It stems from an investigation into Catholic leaders' failings in allowing now-disgraced former American Cardinal Theodore McCarrick to rise in the church hierarchy. https://t.co/CHZdfFPefW

name: NPR
text: Sudan's last democratically elected prime minister, Sadiq al-Mahdi, has died of COVID-19-related complications, his party announced early Thursday. He was 84. https://t.co/hQRtjNVvZw

name: NPR
text:
President-elect Joe Biden is doubling down on his calls for unity and healing. But it's proving a hard sell to many, including Biden’s own supporters. Hoping to help, many around the nation are ramping up trainings for cross-the-aisle conversations.
https://t.co/KCpBKpXhdB

name: NPR
text:
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled late Wednesday to temporarily bar New York from enforcing strict attendance limits on places of worship in areas designated coronavirus hot spots.
https://t.co/4x9uZwlVhn
